Stacks

OK so we have looked briefly at how HTML is like a tree, and trees are one type of abstract data structure.

Well, stacks are another type of abstract data structure.

What’s a stack?

A stack is like a stack of plates at the cafeteria, in one of those plate-holder jobbies.

As you have a new/clean plate to add to the stack, you push it down on the top. (In the fancier models, there’s a spring-loading mechanism that keeps the top of the stack within easy reach.)

When you want a plate, you just grab the one on top.

Push/pop

Adding an item is called pushing onto the stack.

Removing an item is called “popping” (from) the stack.

Stacks in JS

In JavaScript, you can model a stack with an Array. This is built right into the language.

Check it out on MDN:

  • Array.push()
  • Array.pop()

Good old push and pop, sitting right there ready for you to use!

An example

const stackOfPlates = [];

stackOfPlates.push('plate1');
stackOfPlates.push('plate2');
stackOfPlates.push('plate3');
stackOfPlates.push('plate4');

Question: what is the return value when you call stackOfPlates.pop() once?

const plate = stackOfPlates.pop(); // plate4

Ok, yeah, sure, whatever man. Why are you telling us this?

Yes, yes, time is money.

So, stacks as a general data structure are quite important for understanding recursion.

Let’s examine a specific kind of stack: the call stack.
